/dev/null is a printer that prints on in: i presume you use it when you need to see if something hits a "target" inode but dont actually want the results

when you use /dev/null, you want your program to believe that its writes are succeeding. at the same time, you don't care about whatever it's writing, so you're basically just telling your program "yes, yes, don't worry, you're actually writing to a file". but you're lying.
